intro: Siphocampylus convolvulaceus var. weirianus, commonly known as the Weir's morning glory, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It is a climbing vine with heart-shaped leaves and trumpet-shaped flowers that range in color from white to pink. The plant produces showy, fragrant blooms that open in the morning and close by midday. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in woodland edges and along stream banks. Its botanical characteristics make it a distinctive and ornamental species within the Convolvulaceae family.
